Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Comparative Phylogeography and Thermal Ecology of Puerto Rican Anoles
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project investigates the phylogeography of thermal adaptation in Anolis lizards from Puerto Rico. On Puerto Rico, sister-species are morphologically similar but they are divergent in thermal biology, indicating that thermal adaptation has been important for their evolution. Recent models predict that some tropical ectotherms will be unable to adapt fast enough during climate change and therefore they face extinction. This research investigates the processes that lead to local adaptation and provides an important genetic baseline for future studies investigating changes in population genetics, migration, and selection due to anthropogenic climate change. By combining research with training of undergraduates at the University of Washington and the University of Puerto Rico, this proposal provides opportunities for future scientists to learn techniques in field biology and molecular genetics.

By combining physiological experiments and genomic techniques, this research aims to understand the relationship between thermal adaptation and lineage divergence. The goals of this study are: (1) determine how multiple physiologically divergent sister-species evolved, (2) illuminate the phylogeographic and gene flow patterns of species that span thermal gradients, and (3) investigate the relationship between thermoregulation and natural selection. The project uses a multi-species comparative framework to understand the common demographic processes, such as rates of gene flow, geographic isolation, and divergent selection, that generate and maintain local thermally-adapted populations. This research will advance the fields of statistical phylogeography and ecophysiology by utilizing next-generation sequencing and novel analytical methods to test complex models of population divergence and local adaptation. By investigating thermal adaptation in nascent lineages, the results will add the growing literature on the potential for thermal adaptation in tropical ectotherms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant funded research to investigate the relationship between phylogeography, gene flow, and thermal adaptation in Anolis lizards from Puerto Rico. The adaptive radiation of Anolis lizards represents an excellent group for studying the comparative phylogeography of multiple species because the species are abundant and conspicuous, and the ecology, behavior, and eco-physiology of the group are well-studied. On Puerto Rico, sister-species are morphologically similar but they are divergent in thermal biology, indicating that physiological adaptation has been an important in recent speciation events. This research aimed to understand how the ecological and geographic features influence the evolution and adaptation of lizard physiology.

 

Importantly, recent models predict that tropical ectotherms have limited ability for physiological adaptation, and will be forced to migrate, acclimate, or go extinct due to global warming. The intellectual merits of this research are that we utilize a multi-species comparative framework to understand the processes, such as rates of gene flow, geographic isolation, and divergent selection, that generate and maintain local thermally-adapted populations. Our research utilizes next-generation sequencing and novel analytical methods to test complex models of population divergence and local adaptation. We investigated thermal adaptation between species, but also in nascent lineages, which adds to the growing literature on the potential for thermal adaptation in tropical ectotherms.

 

During the tenure of this project we participated in the Upward Bound Math and Science Summer Program (MSUB) at University of Washington. MSUB serves 60 low-income and disadvantaged high school students every year in an effort to expose them to career opportunities in math and science. We organized a 1-week biology education module including lectures by three biology professors, a trip to the Woodland Park Zoo in Seattle, and bird watching on campus. We highlighted this research and the herpetology museum collection at the Burke Museum of Natural History and Culture. During this research we trained one undergraduate, one international graduate student, and one international postdoc in next-generation sequencing techniques. This research was tightly integrated with ongoing population and eco-physiological re-survey work, conducted by R.B. Huey and P.E. Hertz, and we aided them in training 10 undergraduates in field techniques.
